body: @srkukarni is it fine if we can also add Motivation and Modification in PR description. I think it will be helpful for others to understand usecase and reason for the change.
@srkukarni thanks for your review.  I have addressed your comments

I am fine with this change. but just a quick thought: Default if broker throttles dispatching of backlogged subscription then isn't it create more and more backlog.? So, default broker should not throttle backlogged cursor and in case if it requires then it's a dynamic configuration which can be applied at runtime for some special case.
any thought?

>  Default if broker throttles dispatching of backlogged subscription then isn't it create more and more backlog.? So, default broker should not throttle backlogged cursor and in case if it requires then it's a dynamic configuration which can be applied at runtime for some special case.

Yes, that was the reason we had it this way. Though, I agree with @srkukarni  that it's very unintuitive from a user perspective, because "I did set the dispatch rate and I'm not being throttled". 

A better approach could be to have "throttleOnlyBacklogged" flag to be at the namespace level. So that we could do : 
```shell
pulsar-admin namespaces set-dispatch-rate -r 1000 $MY_NAMESPACE --only-when-backlogged
```
Tough that we could add in 2.1

@zhaijack please review this configuration store related documentation change.

@ivankelly please review this topic compaction related commands change.

@HaraldGustafsson thank you for reporting this. we are going to fix it as part of our 2.0 release.
We should try to upgrade to swagger 1.5.19 as well. We're using 1.5.3 from 2015

@bardock 

> if a single bookie goes down

does that mean bookie machine physically gone? or just (docker) process being killed.

if a single bookie goes down is temporary, you can try to set `lostBookieRecoveryDelay` so the auto recovery will kick in later. That would avoid unneeded replication.

if a single bookie goes down is permanently and you don't want to throttle the replication progress, you probably can move autorecovery to detailed hosts.

> Run autorecovery process on dedicated nodes in our BookKeeper cluster. I believe it is not supported in bk version shipped with pulsar 1.20. Is it possible to use bk 4.7 only for autorecovery nodes?

you actually can run `bin/bookkeeper autorecovery` with pulsar package. 

You can check this k8s deployment yaml file - https://github.com/apache/incubator-pulsar/blob/master/deployment/kubernetes/google-kubernetes-engine/bookie.yaml#L183 this is how it  runs bookie autorecovery in separated pods.

Hope this help with your situation.
@pouledodue I had published 1.22.0 binaries for MacOS 10.11 https://pypi.org/project/pulsar-client/#files

As we discussed, #1461 fixed the issue of updating cursors position when all bookies are not writable. 

There is still the issue of loading topics while all bookies are not writable, though it's a separate issue from just clearing backlog on a loaded topic.

Need split and some change, close it and will open new ones
@sijie I'm not sure what's going on. I can't reproduce locally (ran test 100 times in a loop). I'm working on docs right now and will have to circle back to this.
One option is to mark ignored and come back to this but that feels wrong.

Actually looked at the stack trace and it looks like the call to SecureRandom was timing out. I was using it as a simple way to generate nonsense data but it twas overkill, I removed the calls and replaced them with static data.
